question: What is the primary function of a breadboard?
options: To permanently solder electronic components together
To quickly build and modify electronic circuits without soldering
To store electronic components
To test circuit resistance
correctAnswer: To quickly build and modify electronic circuits without soldering

question: Why are the power rails (buses) on a breadboard typically marked with red and black (or blue) lines?
options: To indicate where LEDs should be placed
To help identify the positive and negative connections for power distribution
To show where to insert integrated circuits
To separate different circuit components
correctAnswer: To help identify the positive and negative connections for power distribution

question: What common mistake can prevent an LED from lighting up on a breadboard?
options: Placing the LED leads in different rows
Using a resistor in the circuit
Placing the LED in the correct row
Connecting the LED to the power rail
correctAnswer: Placing the LED leads in different rows

question: What is the advantage of using solid-core wire over stranded wire in a breadboard?
options: Solid-core wire is more flexible and bends easily
Solid-core wire is easier to push into the breadboard and holds connections better
Stranded wire is too thin to conduct electricity
Solid-core wire prevents short circuits
correctAnswer: Solid-core wire is easier to push into the breadboard and holds connections better

question: How should an integrated circuit (IC) be placed on a breadboard?
options: Across the power rails for maximum stability
Straddling the middle gap so each row is connected separately
With all pins inserted into a single row
At the very edge of the breadboard for easy access
correctAnswer: Straddling the middle gap so each row is connected separately
